title: Georgia House - Day 39 (2026-06-25)
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia House - Day 39 (2026-06-25) session:

## Overview
The Georgia House of Representatives held an eventful session on June 25, 2026, with several key actions taken on legislation.

## Key Actions
**HB 1039**: Bill to amend automatic renewal provisions to provide additional protections for consumers - House agreed to Senate amendment.
**HB 1093**: Bill to create an agriculture commodity commission for wine and grapes - House agreed to Senate substitute.

## Bills Introduced (First Reading)
No new bills were introduced.

## Notable Moments
- Debate and explanation of amendments to HB 1039 and HB 1093 by committee chairs.
- Questions and dialogue between representatives on the legislation.

## Votes
- **HB 1039**: House agreed to Senate amendment in a 151-0 vote.
- **HB 1093**: House agreed to Senate substitute in a 150-0 vote.

## Attendance
A quorum was present, with representatives actively participating in the session.

## Adjournment
The House adjourned after completing the day's business. The next legislative session is scheduled for a future date.

House Bill 879 to be entitled back to amend Article 1 of Chapter 3, Title 3 of the official code of Georgia annotated relating to provisions regarding the regulation of alcoholic beverages generally. Chair recognizes Chairman Harrell to explain his motion. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. At your discretion, you might want to turn off the audio and video for a second. I'm going to say some kind words about the Senate. The this bill originated in the House House Bill 879 was the home delivery bill that we passed by an over 2 to 1 margin. And the Senate actually improved it in a number of respects. And let me share those modifications with you. If you have the bill in front of you in Section 1, they've included House Bill 674 authored by Chairman Allen Powell that begins the process of streamlining permitting and renewals for our retailers in combination with the Department of Revenue and their local government. So this begins the process to streamline those renewals, reduce burdens and reduce duplications there. So that's House Bill 674 and Section 1, great improvement. In Section 2, this is an issue we've worked on for a year or two. You will recall back several years ago we passed the so-called brunch bill that requires referendums in local communities. And if it passes in a local community, you could potentially buy for on-premise consumption as early as 11 a.m. What Section 2 does is it maintains all those referendum requirements, but it would allow the local governments to allow for both on-premise and off-premise as early as 11 a.m. So you could also purchase at a croagr, for example, as early as 11 a.m. Once the referendums are passed and they're approved by the local government. So again, I think that is an improvement as well. In Section 3 of the bill, this is basically the delivery bill that we passed previously. And there is one modification, a significant modification, again one that I'm supportive of. When it left the House, it was beer and wine only. And this has included the ability to get packaged spirits through a package store in the delivery portion of the bill. Let me remind everyone here that all those safeguards that were placed in the bill remain. None of that was changed. So it's actually a safer and more documented process to make a purchase through delivery than it is at the counter in any retailer. At the counter in any retailer, they make lants at an ID. They may record a birthday, but in this bill, in every instance, you're going to know the buyers, name, address, photo identification. You're going to know all the information about the drivers. And you're going to know who receives it, including a signature, a guaranteed photo IDs that is scanned and retained. So it's a much safer process through delivery than it is over the counter in any of our retailers. If you have a paper copy, turn to Section 4 beginning on page 13. Again, the Senate has added an issue that we've had here before. This is House Bill 76 that was authored by Chairman Ron Stevens dealing with distances. This measure passed the House by 129 to 34. And what this does is it allows the local government through their local ordinances to reduce the distance with regard to college campuses and college campuses only. It does not change anything with regard to K-12 or churches, but the state distance requirement with regard to college campuses would be a maximum and with local ordinance, local support that locals could make a modification of the distance with regard to college campuses. Those of you that know Savannah well know that there's a wonderful university there, Savannah College of Art and Design, but they've built buildings all over the place. And so they're scattered throughout the community. The same is now true here in Atlanta with Georgia State, Georgia Tech. The same is true in Athens with the University of Georgia. And so this allows the local governments to make a modification on distances if they choose. And then finally, if you'll turn back to page 15, Section 7 is a new chapter. And this is actually a Senate bill that was added here. And it was Senate bill 146 that passed their chamber by a 2-1 margin. This deals with tastings. Today you are able to go into a retailer that sells beer and wine, which could be a grocery store. And as new products come to the market, they may offer you a sample before you buy the product and its package a bottle of wine. But today it's currently illegal to have a similar event inside of a package store. So the tastings in Chapter and Section 7 would permit under very strict circumstances to have tastings inside a package store where the consumer could have a limited amount. And those mounts are listed there. One and a half ounces of spirits, five ounces of wine, eight ounces of beer. Once the local governments have been notified that this event is going to take place inside of a package store. Again, all the safety reporting requirements are unchanged throughout the bill. So I would ask your favorable consideration again. In this case, the Senate, I think, really did a nice job by putting House Bill 674 Chairman Powers streamlining into it, putting the referendum requirements remain the same, but allow for off-premise and on-premise, maintaining our delivery bill with the addition of package stores, and then allowing the distances with regard to college campuses, House Bill 76, which was Chairman Stevens bill, and then finally, the Senate bill dealing with tastings. So with that, Mr. Speaker, I'll be glad to answer questions and ask you to agree with the Senate substitute the House Bill 879. You have a question if you care to yield. Yes, sir. I will be glad to. I would characterize it very differently.
